title: torso suitcase suspect pictured first time
story: Dad-of-two Mahesh Sorathiya, , from Wolverhampton was charged with assisting an offender and granted bail after Phoenix Netts remains were found in the Forest of Dean.Gareeca Conita Gordon, , who lived at the same seven-bed refuge in Birmingham as Phoenix, , has been charged with murder after the grim discovery was made last week.Sorathiya was seen today at Wolverhampton central police station to sign on under his strict bail conditions and a provisional trial date has been set for November  this year.Today, the victims ex-boyfriend described her as kind and quiet who had struggled with the trauma of a previous sexual assault.Meanwhile, Phoenixs friend from university - named Fawn - described the young woman as someone who would give you her last penny.She told the MailOnline: It makes me sick that somebody could kill her and then cut her body up.Phoenix was a kind and considerate woman.We had great times at university. But she did have mental health issues and when I spoke to her about eight months ago on Facebook, she wasn’t in a good place.But I am so saddened at what has happened to her.Tragically, the young womans body was found by Gloucestershire Police last Tuesday night after the driver of a Vauxhall was spotted with concerns they were flouting the coronavirus lockdown.Officers discovered the body parts stuffed in two suitcases. It is understood there had been attempts to burn the remains.Prosecutor James Ward QC told the court this week: When they opened the suitcases, the police said it smelled of barbecue and the smell was sickening from the decomposition.The ex-boyfriend of Phoenix said today that he had gone to Canterbury Christ Church University with her between  and  where she had trained to become a paramedic - but she didnt graduate.He told the Mail Online: She told me and one other friend of hers that she had been raped by a drug dealer.Phoenix was kind and quiet, but also vulnerable. She didn’t have a great childhood after her parents had split up. I was ignorant to peoples’ mental health at the time, so I wouldn’t have been able to analyse then as I can now.But she seemed damaged, and rightly so, by the trauma she went through. I don’t know which way her le went after we split up, but it clearly went south.She never expressed any interest in kids or getting married.The Times today revealed Gordon, , lived in the room opposite to Phoenix in the seven-bedroom terraced property in Lozells.It is understood Phoenix had grown up in Croydon, south London before relocating to the Midlands - later moving into the womens refuge late last year.Her family issued an emotional statement in response to her tragic death on May .It read: “As a family we are devastated with what has happened to Phoenix.“We have family and good friends supporting us and our thanks go out to all of them.“We would also like to thank all the police officers involved in the investigation for their hard work and sensitivity.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadn’t seen her in a while.Detective Chief Inspector Scott Grfiths from our homicide team said: “Firstly, I’d like to offer my sincere condolences to Phoenix’s family.“We’ve worked closely with colleagues at Gloucestershire over the past week and our investigation continues at pace.“We’d urge anyone with any information about the tragic loss of Phoenix’s le to get in touch with us.

title: britain first leader paul golding
story: Golding, , was stopped at Heathrow Airport on October  last year on his way back from Moscow by officers from the politan Police.He refused to give the pin codes for an iPhone and Apple computer and was later charged with wilfully refusing to comply with a duty under Schedule  of the Terrorism Act.Golding, the leader of the far-right political group, denied the charge but was found guilty of the offence following a trial at Westminster Magistrates Court in London on Wednesday.Chief magistrate Emma Arbuthnot ruled there was no doubt that Golding had failed to comply with requests for information, despite his obligations being explained to him and being warned over and over thathe did not he risked arrest.She handed Golding a conditional discharge for nine months and ordered him to pay a £ surcharge and £ in costs.Ms Arbuthnot said Golding had been lawfully questioned and that under Schedule  there had been no requirement for reasonable suspicion for the stop.PC Rory OConnor, a borders officer with the Met who questioned Golding, told the court that Schedule  enables accredited officers to speak to people in order to make a determination of whether they are or have been concerned in the commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism.The officer explained that it also permitted police to interrogate, search and detain anyone for up to six hours at UK ports.He said he had cause to examine Golding under the legislation and recalled him being initially agitated and clearly angry at being stopped, with him shouting at officers.Prosecutor Samuel Main said that for nearly three hours Golding was questioned about his activities in Russia after flying out with two others on October .The court heard that Golding said he was on a purely political trip after establishing friendships in Russia during an international congress on an earlier date.He told officers that he had ed to the country under the invitation of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia , which he described as a right wing, conservative, patriotic group who were not extreme.English Defence League founder Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, watched the proceedings in the courts socially distanced public gallery.Over the course of his three-day trip, Golding gave interviews to the media, met members of the LDPR and visited the Russian parliament, Mr Main said.He also visited Moscows Red Square and laid a wreath at the tomb of the unknown soldier.In audio recording of the interview played in court, Golding said the request for his pin codes was wildly inappropriate, completely unjustied, and was a political witch hunt.Mr Main said he told officers they hadnt asked him about terrorism or criminality and he was simply a politician.Britain First was deregistered as a political party in November .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: primary schools defy plans reopen councils revolt
story: SOME , English primary schools are set to defy plans to reopen on June  — despite doctors dropping their opposition.At least  councils have joined the growing revolt and warned their schools could stay shut on the date.Analysis by The Sun found the local authorities cover , primaries.Ministers want kids in reception, Year  and Year  to head back first on June ,scientists give it the go-ahead.If  kids in each of these council schools are denied the chance to , , will be forced to stay at home.The revolt comes despite a pledge by the PM to get a national Covid tracing operation up and running by June , meeting a key demand of council chiefs.The British Medical Association, which represents doctors, dropped its hardline opposition to reopening.In a massive softening of its position, the BMA said schools can reopen on June  “as long as it is safe to do so”.It pointed out there is “growing evidence” the risk Covid- poses to kids is “extremely small”.And it called for ministers and teachers to “work together to allow schools to reopen safely”.Children’s commissioner Anne Longfield has told unions and ministers to “stop squabbling” and agree a plan to get kids back to class.Ministers and some of Labour’s big beasts, including Alan Johnson and David Blunkett, have warned poor kids are losing out the most from the schools shutdown.But Cllr Judith Blake, from the Local Government Association, demanded councils are allowed to keep their schools shut for longerthey want.He must remember that they are led by Corbynites engaging in a political war against the Brexit-backing Tory Government which they detest for destroying their dreams last December.But we do agree with the unions on one thing. If the advice from Sage’s scientists is that ing to school is safe, publish it in full. Then the public, the teachers and their unions can see it.The PM must then order schools to , once they have finalised social distancing measures.If the NEU wants to strike, it can ­ballot members.If local councils refuse to open schools, the Government MUST sanction them. A quarter may switch institutions.Dr Gavan Conlon said the such a deferral rate would have “severe financial consequences” for universities.Hardline unions have drawn up a list of  health and safety demands before teachers go back to class.Tonight Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said schools across England shouldat the same time.He told the daily Downing Street press conference: “It is best, and the Government has said this repeatedly.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says steve coogan greed furlough
story: How does a man worth £million defend sponging off taxpayers to fund the bulk of his laid-off housekeeper and gardener’s salaries  Especially a man so very keen to judge the morality of others It’s not illegal. But the Government furlough system was set up as a fallback to keep people in jobs, not to protect the wealth of multi-millionaires or billionaires by paying their staff for them.Many families who can afford cleaners have dug deep to keep them solvent during this crisis. They have not demanded the public bail them out.Coogan could pay his staff in full without denting even a fraction of the interest on his riches. Instead he chose to make taxpayers do it.That’s greed, all right. As for the comic’s risible claim that “I don’t get anything for free”, it’s not true now, is it It is equally repugnant that Foxtons magnate Jon Hunt has kept his £.billion dry by getting the public to pay his  furloughed country club workers.At least Victoria Beckham changed her mind after belatedly realising from the public outcry how wrong it was for a woman as rich as she is to make a claim.The UK faces a recession of unprecedented scale, with millions unemployed and the Treasury’s depleted coffers struggling to keep us afloat.Let us never forget those mega-rich celebrity hypocrites who abused the State’s generosity during the Covid crisis and brought ordinary people’s ruin even closer.BORIS Johnson must show stronger leadership over getting kids back to school.The softening-up of the June  restart date for primaries betrays a man cowed by the storm the unions whipped up.He must remember that they are led by Corbynites engaging in a political war against the Brexit-backing Tory Government which they detest for destroying their dreams last December.But we do agree with the unions on one thing. If the advice from Sage’s scientists is that ing to school is safe, publish it in full.Then the public, the teachers and their unions can see it.The PM must then order schools to , once they have finalised social distancing measures.If the NEU wants to strike, it can ­ballot members.If local councils refuse to open schools, the Government MUST sanction them. And Sir Keir Starmer’s Labour must decide whether to side with the hard-Left over working people.Boris’s drt is worrying. title: coronavirus shows we got out just in time now someone switch the eu ventilator off
story: But there’s one thing the pandemic has made absolutely clear — we were right, beyond all doubt, to leave the European Union.The EU is in desperate trouble. Its vast bureaucratic institutions were utterly unable to react to the threat of the virus.So the inidual countries did it all for themselves. Each following a dferent policy. When the moment came, the EU was found wanting. Lethargic, hopeless and riven with internal dispute.There is fury in Spain that the EUwon’t bung them loads of money for being badly hit by the virus.It’s the same in Italy, where  per cent of the population now want to LEAVE the EU. The country that was usually one of the EU’s biggest cheerleaders.A disillusion with the EU is spreading across the continent.People are beginning to see that it’s a good thing to have control of your borders. And that the best way of controlling those borders is through a nation state.The Greeks have been trying to contain a mass influx of refugees from Turkey — and getting no help from the EU in the process. Some senior EU politicians fear that the virus could kill off the EU altogether. Right now it’s on a ventilator and looking very sorry for itself.We can only hope — for the good of our European friends — that someone switches that ventilator off.Once we all emerge from lockdown there will be a financial price to pay. Our economy — the world’s economy — has taken a hell of a battering.But the good news is that we will be in with a much better chance of a full recovery than the EU bloc.From  you will no longer have to pay tarfs on a vast range of goods imported from beyond Europe.I suspect it will lead to a consumer bonanza — which is just what we want. Washing machines, freezers, women’s sanitary products, bicycle inner tubes, Christmas trees — the list of stuff which will be cheaper is almost endless.It’s true thatthe EU refuses to soften its stance about a trade deal with us, then we’ll pay more for cars made on the continent.But even that might have its upside. It will encourage people to buy British. Last year Brits bought only , cars that had been manufactured in the UK. The majority of cars were bought from German plants. Your loss, Germany.The EU negotiators are still being intransigent. They still think they can bully this country.Michael Gove has told them to get real. Sort out an acceptable trade deal for the good of the entire European economy.But eventhey don’t — evenreality fails to establish itself inside their closed minds— it will be the EU that loses out.It wouldn’t surprise me hugelyCovid- outlasted the European Union, frankly. We should all breathe a sigh of relief that we got the hell out of that helpless institution.Just in time.I WONDERCovid- will see an end to hard cash  My local shopkeepers tell me that almost no transactions in the past two months have been paid in cash. It’s all done by card.I’ve had the same  quid in my pocket that was there on March .I bet we don’t go back to paying in cash once this is over. Queuing for ages behind some addled berk at the ATM who is incapable of pressing the right buttons. Cash is going the way of the dinosaurs.And it’s not too far of a stretch to suggest that offices might be on their way out, either. Hugely expensive things to run, offices. And the original reason we had them was to store paper – files and so on. Don’t really need that any more, do we  People have discovered that working from home has many benefits. Not least the pleasure of avoiding pointless meetings with idiots.And for those who feel the need to get away from their families on a daily basis there’s “co-working environments”, or “the park with a load of booze”, as I like to call it.MOST lady slebs are busy during lockdown taking pictures of themselves wearing almost no clothes.Either to advertise products nobody really wants or to advertise themselves. For which many thanks, girls.Scarcely a day goes by without one of them taking a perfectly natural selfie of herself with hardly any clothes on, pouting at the camera like a trout with a botched facelt.Model Rosie Huntington-Whiteley has gone a stage further and posted pics of herself taken  years ago. Just in case we’d forgotten.I might get in on the act. Next week I’ll take a selfie wearing a leather thong and nipple clamps, advertising my new skincare product made from vole’s urine.Watch this space.I’m not so sure. Boredom is a greatly underrated virtue. It makes you get off your backside and do something. And our kids have been bored senseless for two months now.You never know, this break might do the kids some good. Fire their imaginations or something.And better still – it means they’re not having left-wing drivel drilled into their heads by the teachers…THE English Football League is in a right old mess.None of its three isions can agree what to do about finishing the season.The clubs in the lowest tier, ision two, have voted to end the season immediately. Those in the Championship want to finish the season, while League One clubs haven’t a clue.There’s talk of Coventry and Rotherham being promoted and a play-off between the next EIGHT clubs.I know a lot of money is at stake. I know the league has signed big deals with the broad- casters. But the sensible thing surely would have been to call the season null and void, across all three isions.Those of us who, like me, support clubs who had a chance of promotion will get over our disappointment.There are more important things than football.So let’s look at Sweden. It became the country with the highest death rate per capita from Covid- in Europe during thesevendays to May .The lockdown has unquestionably saved lives.LAST Friday night I was called  times in the space of an hour by the SAME NUMBER.What’s more, my phone told me the call was coming from Tajikistan. But every time I tried to answer, the caller hung up. That’s totally unfair.I have never in my le spoken to a person from Tajikistan. And I would very much like to do so. It might be interesting.I’m sure it was a criminal of some kind, but that’s not the point.I wanted to knowmy caller was a member of the mysterious Yaghnobi people, who live in the mountains in the north of the country, with their many goats. That would have been exciting.I might start ringing up numbers in Tajikistan indiscriminately. And then move on to Kyrgyzstan.That’s what lockdown does to you.For this they have been attacked by “human rights activists”.Perhaps.But not by the people of Hungary, who fully agree with this measure.Much as I suspect people would over here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cops last known cctv image tesco
story: The CCTV still shows Louise Smith at a Tesco supermarket the night before she disappeared from her home in Havant, Hants, on VE Day.Louse was last seen around midday on May  after telling pals she was popping out briefly.She was due tohome to spend the weekend with her boyfriend, who had come over to stay.Detectives managed to trace her mobile phone to a skate park before it was switched off two hours later.Cops have released CCTV of Louise captured at a Tescostore on Greywell Road that she visited around .pm on May .Officers hunting for the missing youngster hope the photos will jog someones memory.A man and woman, both , were arrested on suspicion of kidnap last Friday have now been released on bail.Volunteers from the Isle of Wight Search and Rescue team have also joined the hunt in Hampshire, Berkshire, Sussex and Surrey.After her phone was switched off around pm on that day, family had said, Louise had not been seen or heard from despite constant door-to-door inquiries being carried out by police.Louise is described as: white, around ft ins tall, slim, and straight, black, shoulder- hair.Detectives urged residents in Leigh Park to check their CCTV in case the schooolgirl appears on it.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said:  As part of our ongoing inquiries to find Louise, we are not only trying to trace her movements since this time, but also in the previous  hours, so that we have a clear understanding of where she had been and who she may have spoken to.We know she was in the Tescostore, in Greywell Road, shortly before .pm the night before she was reported missing, Thursday May , and we are today able to share that image with you, in the hope it may jog your memory.Perhaps you saw her on Thursday May , either before or after she was in the store Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: siberia heatwave hottest spring
story: Temperatures soared in the foothills of the Altai Mountain foothills shattering May weather records and sparking shocking wildfires.To keep cool during the unseasonal scorcher locals have been hitting lakeside beaches in a region more famous as the coldest inhabited place on the planet.Areas in western Siberia have reported temperatures of C to C -  far hotter than typical for the time of year.In one of many freak weather consequences, ice at Arctic port of Dudinka on the Yenisei River melted a full month before its usual time of early June.To the south in Kransoyarsk ticks are swarming some  times more than normal, carrying the threat of encephalitis and Lyme disease.More than , people have reported tick bites in Kemerovo region, and further west in Tyumen doctors have registered  cases a day, said head of regional infectious hospital Galina PolushkinaA record number of wildfires have raged earlier than usual in Siberia, with hundreds of houses and two million hectares destroyed by the end of April.There are fears for harvests due to the excessive early heat.Apple and cherry trees which normally bloom at the end of May were in full blossom in late April.Its like there was no spring and we moved from the end of winter with metres-high piles of snow straight into summer, radio journalist Sergey Zubchuk told The Siberian Times.There was no spring, no weeks-long gentle rise of temperature. Somebody just clicked the hot air switch at the end of April, and summer began.Im Siberian-born and lived here for  years, I dont remember a single spring like this.Experts predict anomalous warm temperatures - up to C higher than typical - in western Siberia and the Arctic Circle in the coming days.Overall, Russia averaged C above normal during the first four months of .Oil city Surgut reported C in mid-May, some ten degrees above the norm.The heat wave came to us from the southwest, almost Iran, said Professor Alexey Kozhukhovskiy for the Siberian Federal University.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pub landlords demand two metre rule is halved 37000
story: PUB landlords have demanded that the two-metre social distancing rule is halved because it could leave over , boozers unable to open.The industry’s largest trade association has said the majority of pubs could openthe rule is changed, but that  per cent would otherwise stay closed.Industry leaders have claimed that companies will be bankruptedstaff and customers have to keep two metres apart.Ministers have said that some areas of the hospitality industry could start to open in July, but that social distancing measures will be implemented.George Eustice, the environment secretary, said government was “working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place”.This could see only large pubs or those with gardens allowed to reopen.The sector’s largest trade body, however, has warned this would wreak havoc on the industry.Emma McClarkin, chief executive of the British Beer and Pub Association, told The Times that “at two metres you’re probably looking at only  per cent of pubs being able to operate.”With an estimated , pubs and bars in the UK, this could see over , forced to keep their doors closed.Ms McClarkin noted, however, that a one-metre rule “would put the majority of pubs back in play”.She added: “It becomes extraordinarily dficult without some flexibility in the guidelines. There are pubs that haven’t even got a two-metre radius around the bar so that rules them out.”The UK and Spain are the only European countries using a two-metre rule, with the World Health Organisation recommending one metre.David Moore, the owner of Michelin starred Pied à Terre in London, said the current rule “would be a disaster” for the industry.He said that the government should “trust operators to get it right, we don’t want to endanger our team or our customers.”Proposals to reopen the sector were released by UKHospitality yesterday.The -page document said that drinkers will be banned from standing at bars, and suggested that restaurants get rid of salt and pepper shakers.Their recommendations also included using contactless ordering through an app, staff wearing masks and gloves and social distancing signage on the walls and floor.It comes as some pub owners have started serving booze in takeaway glasses and bottles.Pictures posted on social media show people downing their first drinks from their locals since pubs and bars were closed on March .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The GMB host bashed the London mayor for hiking the congestion charge to £ a day this week, sparking outcry from key workers.More than , people have signed a petition calling for all key workers to be exempt, and now Mr Khan has been forced to defend the policy in a heated interview.Piers asked who set the new £ charge, and who extended the hours that it applies to.Mr Khan insisted: “The Government says we have to widen the scope, so it’s TFL, it’s us.”Rounding on the Labour politician, Mr Morgan insisted: “It’s you.“You decided the scope, own the scope you then went for.”He asked: “Are all these essential workers having to pay these punitive extra charges to use their cars ”The mayor replied: “Had I not widened the scope or increased the charges Id have been in breach of the agreement.“Those who work in the NHS or those who work in care homes are exempt from the conditions.”The telly host asked: “What about teachers, police officers, firefighters  They are all paying it right ”Mr Khan replied: “The intention is for all others to pay the congestion charge when it changes.”A furious Piers interrupted, saying: “You are really going to charge essential workers £ a week to use their car during a crisis of this magnitude when they have to go to work often in order to save our lives “Is anything ever your fault “You made it impossible for many to use their cars, what are they going to do ”The charge does not apply to workers in the NHS or care homes.The congestion charge will go up from £. to £ from June st, and the hours it will apply will be extended.Its currently only applied between am and pm on a week day, but will be extended to pm and run seven days a week.The  per cent hike will particularly hit white van man and other tradespeople who have to travel around the capital for work.The Mayor has blamed the Government for forcing him to act - title: sturgeons roadmap easing lockdown today
story: NICOLA Sturgeon will set out a four-phase blueprint for Scotland to begin easing lockdown restrictions today.Scotland has now been in full lockdown for almost three months and has refused to follow the Prime Ministers relaxation of restrictions last week.Ms Sturgeon will make her speech at .pm today, after she said she did not have confidence in Boris Johnsons decision to allow Brits more freedom.The Scottish leader has insisted all the evidence pointed towards having to continue with the same rules and while England shted towards a stay alert message, Scotland continued stay-at-home orders.Ms Sturgeon was highly critical of the new stay alert messaging, calling it imprecise and vague.She said: “Our assessment of the evidence leads me to conclude that the lockdown must be extended at this stage.“We know that progress remains fragile, our estimates suggest there are still signicant amounts of people in Scotland infected with this virus.Any signicant easing of restrictions at this stage would be very, very risky indeed.People in Scotland have not been allowed to spend leisure time outside and are only allowed to travel locally for exercise.Those measures were eased by Mr Johnson last week when he encouraged anyone who couldnt work from home to head back to work, and said people could travel to beauty spots and have picnics.The PMs statement caused a fracturing within the UK as devolved administrations refused to follow Englands lead.Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford gave people a stern warning not to travel to Wales - saying they would be finedthey made non-essential travel.Ms Sturgeon is expected to lay out when Scottish children will be able to head back to schools.She has previously warned they may not be back behind desks until after the summer holidays.When asked about plans for English schools to reopen on June , Ms Sturgeon said she did not think it was the right thing to do.She said: I cannot and should not comment on whether that is appropriate for England … but I do know, looking at the evidence I have now, I could not put my hand on my heart and say that would be a safe thing to do in Scotland.English school kids are due to title: uk reject eu border post demand
story: Government documents published on Wednesday confirmed there will need to be checks on some goods entering Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK from January next year once the Brexit transition period has ended.But it rejected the EU’s demands for new infrastructure to be introduced to carry out the checks. Instead they will expand existing border screening to carry out the additional checks.And the government documents made clear that the checks will be conducted by UK border officials, snubbing EU demands to have their own personnel carrying out checks.It set up another big row with Brussels, which wanted to install a permanent base in Northern Ireland to oversee the checks.But Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove, who unveiled the UK plans in the Commons on Wednesday, admitted that Northern Ireland will have to follow EU rules on agriculture and manufactured goods until at least .The key concession will ensure access to the EU’s single market and keep the border with the Republic of Ireland free-flowing in order to maintain the Northern Ireland Peace Agreement.The Government paper said having a so-called “mini-EU embassy” in Belfast would be “isive” and called on Brussels to “respect the UK’s territorial integrity”.It also promised Northern Ireland businesses would benefit from “unfettered access” when selling goods to the rest of the UK. It ended a row over whether checks would be in place on goods entering the UK from Northern Ireland.Mr Gove, minister in charge of Brexit preparations, said: Our proposals will deliver unfettered access for Northern Ireland businesses to the whole of the UK market ensure there are no tarfs on goods remaining within the UK customs territory discharge our obligations without the need for any new customs infrastructure in Northern Ireland and, finally, guarantee that Northern Ireland businesses benefit from the lower tarfs we deliver through our new free trade agreements with third countries.The plans were given a cautious initial welcome by the EU last night, who said they will be monitoring the implementation of the Northern Ireland Protocol closely.A European Commission spokesman said: “The detailed legal commitments set out in the Protocol must now be implemented precisely to give full effect to this solution.The time to implement the Protocol is short, and practical implementation measures must start immediately so that the Protocol can be operational by  January . To this end, the Commission stands ready to work with the UK authorities.”In a further sign of relations souring between the two sides, the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier last night hit out at the “tone” of his opposite number David Frost.He said a “new dynamism” was needed in talksthe two sides are to avoid a “stalemate”.Mr Barnier was hitting back at a furious letter from Mr Frost that was highly critical of the EU’s rigid approach to the negotiations.Mr Frost said Brussels proposed deal contains novel and unbalanced proposals which would bind this country to EU law or standards.He said: What is on offer is not a fair free trade relationship between close economic partners, but a relatively low-quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions.”In his reply, Mr Barnier said he did not think an exchange of letters regarding the substance of the negotiations is necessarily the best way to discuss on substantial points.He added: It cannot be a substitute for serious engagement and detailed negotiations and, in particular, I would not like the tone that you have taken to impact the mutual trust and constructive attitude that is essential between us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. The crumbling estate is owned by the elusive property tycoons Heinrich and Dwora Feldman through their business Manaquel Company Ltd. The couple, now in their eighties, were placed at number  in the Sunday Times Rich List published last weekend, which put their wealth at £million. What immediately strikes you about Dorchester Court in Lambeth, South London, are the wooden beams holding up the balconies because the brickwork and steel supports have corroded. Ben Archard lives on the estate with his we Emmanuelle and two children and says pleas to the landlord to carry out repairs date back to the s. “Dorchester Court could be such an amazing place to live,” he says. “The architects designed somewhere that wasnapost just nice to look at, it was built in a way that brings its residents together into a community. “The crying shame is that the landlord doesnapost respect, or even understand, what he has. For years weaposve been trying to get the buildings looked after, the conditions here are awful, but all weaposve had inis bad management, neglect and a selfish desire to treat the place as a cash cow. Itaposs just so frustrating and demoralising. “Now the landlord wants to build  flats on top of the roofs without even committing to fixing the existing problems, and he plans to evict most of the residents to do it. “Dorchester Court and our wonderful community deserve so much better than this. We need something to change soon or it may become too late to save the place. “We have just received a report from a structural engineer which states ‘It is obvious that the lack of regular maintenance has accelerated the deterioration of the buildings’.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPlans to reopen schools have been plunged into chaos - as a government minister admits Englandaposs primaries might not all open on June . Englandaposs primaries were told to prepare to bring back year R,  and  pupils back to class, with other primary years ing later in June.  But those plans were hurled into doubt by a mass revolt from unions and councils. Liverpool, Hartlepool, Birmingham, and even Tory-run Solihull and Essex have warned June  might not be possible. Some are looking at later dates, some are still waiting to see what will happen, and some are suggesting s may be part-time - despite the government saying this isnapost an option.Schools are of course already open for vulnerable children and those of key workers. But plans to open them more widely - which involves halving class sizes, hiding away toys, having staggered breaks and making corridors one-way - have ided many in the teaching profession. They need time to prepare, and also want to see the full scientic evidence on whether itaposll be safe. Scientists have also said the government should wait until after a delayed test, track and trace app is up and running. AskedLabour would back councils refusing to open on June , a spokesman for Keir Starmer said: “Ultimately councils will want to do what is in the best interests of children and families in their respective area. The infection rate ies from area to area so it’s not surprising some councils have particular concerns.” The government has insisted the June  date was at the earliest and schools wouldnapost be reopenedit was unsafe. Today one minister, Robert Buckland, admitted they may not open unormly across England. In Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland they will remain shut to the wider population. So what have dissenting councils in England said  Hereaposs what we know so far. These are all the areas weaposve found so far expressing doubt about the governmentaposs plans. But the situation is changing fast so itaposs inevitable some are probably left out. If you know one which should be added to this list, please e-mail dan.bloom@mirror. Barking and Dagenham Council leader Darren Rowell: “I cannot support any school reopeningit puts at risk the safety of our teachers, staff and young people.. Simply forcing schools to reopen without taking steps to reduce the risk of the virus spread is unacceptable… We can’t put people at risk by rushing back to normality before it’s safe.” Birmingham We only support Birmingham schools opening to more pupils when it is safe to do so. We are committed to having due regard to the guidance that has been issued by the government. However, we recognise that for some schools, opening to more pupils safely may not be possible on  June.  Bradford Bradford Council has no intention of directing schools to open on June  or to force parents to send their children back and we are committed to working in partnership with school leaders, families and trade unions so that they can make sure their schools are safe environments for our children whenever they choose to open. Parents will not be finedthey choose not to send their children back to school at this time. Brighton and Hove We have strongly advised our schools that they should only reopen to more children when their risk assessments indicate it is safe to do so. It is likely that wider re-opening will happen at dferent times for dferent schools and for dferent numbers of children, given each school’s particular circumstances. Bristol Mayor Marvin Rees: You cannot just make a blanket statement on Bristol. What we’ve said is we will back our schools to make the decision they have to make. Bury While high levels of Covid- infection in the north west remain, and guidance around practical arrangements for social distancing within educational environments, testing and tracing, and supply of PPE is unclear, the borough will not be re-opening schools on June .  Calderdale Adam Wilkinson, lead member for children and young people: We are advising schools in Calderdale not to extend opening on  June. We are keen to get more pupils back to school, but safety is of paramount importance  we have been advised by public health professionals that governments key tests have not been met. Durham Schools in County Durham are being advised that they should only start a phased reopening when they feel it is safe to do so.  Essex Whilst all schools are working hard to respond to the guidance provided by the Department for Education, depending on each inidual school context, some primary, infant and junior schools may not be able to offer full-time provision for the relevant year groups, and any new arrangements may not be introduced exactly from the st June. Gateshead We have absolute confidence that each school will determine the risk, and will make the right decision for their schools, pupils, staff and parents. The council will fully support any school that after careful consideration of all these factors, determines that they cannot comply with government instruction. Hartlepool We have agreed [schools] will not reopen on Monday  June. Whilst we recognise the importance of schools reopening, we want to be absolutely clear that we will be taking a measured and cautious approach to this. We continue to work with schools to put in place appropriate measures to help keep children and staff safe when a phased reopening is possible.”

title: calls urgent public inquiry uk
story: NewsCalls for urgent public inquiry into UK coronavirus response as death toll hits ,EXCLUSIVE: Top scientists and health professionals warn that lessons must be learned from the handling of the deadly disease before a second spike hits the UKShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY NewsPM Boris Johnson addresses the nation about coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Top scientists and health professionals are calling for an urgent public inquiry into the Government’s response to the coronavirus pandemic.They warn that lessons must be learned from the handling of the deadly disease before a second spike or thousands more lives will be needlessly lost. The experts branded the death toll in care homes a “scandal” and attacked the Government for failing to deal adequately with the first wave of Covid-. More than , people have signed a petition calling for an independent inquiry launched by campaign group March for Change. Ministers have not yet agreed to a public inquiry but have accepted that there will have to be a moment where they have to look back. At the No  briefing, Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: “Of course in any public health crisis there will be a time for lessons to be learned afterwards.” For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog HERE. But Justice Secretary Robert Buckland added: “It would be very dficult now to judge what happened in March, bearing in mind the change in our knowledge.” Labour leader Keir Starmer has said it was “inevitable” there would be an official inquiry but the party has not yet called for one.However, it has demanded a probe into Covid- deaths in care homes, saying staff and residents had been tragically let down. Dr Kailash Chand, former deputy chair of the BMA Council, said: “The UK is a world-leader in the fields of science and healthcare, and our NHS is the envy of the world. “Despite this, we now have the highest number of deaths in Europe and the situation in our care homes is nothing short of a scandal. “Governments and media from across the globe, from Australia to Germany, are using the UK as an example of how not to tackle the crisis.  “It is time that we, the public, hold this government to account by demanding an urgent and independent public inquiry.” His concerns were echoed by Professor Dame Anne Glover, President of the Royal Society of Edinburgh who said: “More than  in  of coronavirus deaths worldwide have been in the UK. The UK government has struggled to deliver an effective response. “Faced with the potential of a second wave this winter, compounded with seasonal flu, we now need an urgent and independent public inquiry to ensure we all learn the lessons while we still have time to prepare.” Professor Martin McKee, professor of European Public Health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, added: “We clearly failed in the first wave and, with the possibility of a second wave come winter, we must make every effort to learn the lessons and be better prepared. “The public inquiry must be fast, independent and transparent to ensure we never again allow our NHS and care workers – and all key workers – to fight this battle without the adequate support and protection.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPunters could be stopped from drinking at the bar at pubs as part of new proposals aimed at helping hospitality firms reopen on July .Restrictions on the number of children in outdoor playing areas and patrols of smoking areas have also been put forward among potential measures touted to help sites meet coronavirus guidelines.Trade group UKHospitalityhas put forward the initial proposals alongside other industry leaders, in a -page draft document submitted to ministers.Earlier this month, Boris Johnson said that some hospitality firms could be able to reopen from July  at the earliest in the Governmentaposs third phase of the lockdown.For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. Pubs, restaurants and hotels have remained closed since shutting their doors in March, with vast numbers of staff supported by the Governmentaposs furlough scheme. In the guidance, hospitality businesses claried that they do not wish to move ahead with reopening before the time is right and support a phased reopening approach. The proposals for restaurants suggest that condiments would not be left on tables, with inidually wrapped sauces and condiments handed out by staff on request.  Restaurants would also need to bring cutlery with customersapos food, rather than leave them on tables or allow customers to help themselves. Tables would also be spaced in the restaurant to meet social distancing guidelines. Meanwhile, the guidance suggests that restrictions on customers remaining at the bar after ordering and getting their drink should be considered.  It also proposed that customers are discouraged from ing empty glasses, customers are told to keep a safe distance away from bar staff and they will have to form a socially-distanced queue for orders. Tape on the floor showing the appropriate distance needed and customers collecting drinks from a pick up point are also among the measures suggested. Pubs will also have to put in place a plan for toilets to ensure they donapost become overcrowded.  Kate Nicholls, chief executive officer of UKH, said: UKH is working hard with our members and alongside other industry bodies to develop practical and effective guidelines to enable businesses to begin to reopen safely when the time is right. These are draft guidelines that have been shared with governments in England, Scotland and Wales, to help inform their thinking around reopening. We hope that the guidelines will help businesses draw up their own plans based on their premises, ensuring that safety is at the forefront of operations when the right time comes to reopen. It comes as pub bosses took advantage of a loophole in the easing of lockdown rules to serve scorched Brits as temperatures soared to C yesterday. Thirsty punters shared photos of themselves enjoying pints in disposable cups across social media on Wednesday as landlords re-opened their boozers for takeaways only. Bar staff were snapped bringing drinks outside in full PPE while one pub in Bournemouth saw huge snaking queues of delighted customers. This weekaposs mini-heatwave peaked yesterday - smashing the hottest day of the year record set on Tuesday - with many Brits more desperate than ever to enjoy a pint after weeks in lockdown.

story: NewsBritish Magaluf bar worker found dead in wardrobe at her home near party stripDanielle Finlay Brookes was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the brash Punta Ballena strip. Friends have described her as a girl "full of fun and laughter"ShareCommentsByGerard Couzens:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDanielle Finlay Brookes was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the famous Magaluf resort’s beach " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British Magaluf bar worker was reportedly found dead inside a wardrobe at her home near the famous party resort. Danielle Finlay Brookes was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the brash Punta Ballena strip. Local reports said she had been discovered leless inside a wardrobe at the property before police arrived after a concerned neighbour managed to get in. Police could not be reached early this morning for an official comment but it is understood Danielle’s death is not being treated as suspicious at this stage. Well-wishers have already donated nearly £, towards a GoFundMe appeal set up to raise money towards repatriation and funeral costs. One of the two expats who set up the fundraising site is Meghan Tattersall, who was badly hurt in a hate-fuelled hit-and-run in Magaluf in May  when she was mowed down by the ex-girlfriend of her new partner. Kemi Coaker, , from Manchester, was handed a two-year suspended jail sentence in May last year after confessing to running over Meghan, , from Leeds, after a plea bargain deal. Sales rep Meghan said in a Facebook tribute on Wednesday: “Your are my best friend and my angel high in the sky. I’m truly heartbroken. “I’m so proud to be able to spend everyday with you. Fly high my princess. RIP to my girl I’m so proud of. I love you.” [sic] Another pal, Jay Burton, said of the tragic expat, originally from Crewe, Cheshire: “Absolutely devastated to hear the news Danielle Finlay Brookes. “You were the le of the party everywhere you were. Hope you rest in peace. Magaluf won’t be the same without you.” He added in a later post: “Sending all my love to everyone  who is struggling through this tough time. “Being stuck indoors, with your mind doing somersaults, thinking you’re not good enough, with the biggest challenge of the day being putting a smile on your face.  “Thinking no-one would careyou just didn’t wake up the next day. “Today seeing all the support from the Maga family after losing an amazing girl who cared for everyone, makes me realise how le is too short and many people actually do care. “To all my friends and family, please check on those you haven’t heard from in a while.” Danielle, who described herself on social media as a “Queen building her own empire” had worked in Magaluf for several years. She is thought to have lived alone. She was described as a worker at the Three Lions Karaoke bar in October  when she filmed Spanish police hitting a female tourist as she tried to break up a fight between two men.  She wrote alongside the footage, which was posted on a Facebook page for Magaluf residents: “Spanish Guardia for you - attacking a girl for no reason.” She later wrote an impassioned statement about the incident, moaning Brits in the party resort were treated worse than muggers and prostitutes she claimed were “free to roam the streets.” Emotional pal Rob Dury said: “No words can describe how much all your friends and family will miss that smile. “A beautul young woman taken too soon. Thanks for being you. I will miss your hugs and chats.” The latest tragedy comes just less than a month after the death of another much-loved Magaluf bar worker, -year-old Irishman Anthony Ennis.  He plunged to his death from his eighth-floor apartment in the party resort just after am on April . Anthony, believed to be from Waterville, Co Kerry, worked at the well-known Stereo Bar in Magaluf. He was described as a “diamond of a bloke” by one friend after it emerged he had died. The results of an investigation into his death have not been made public but police are not understood to be treating the incident as a crime. Like Danielle, popular Anthony was gearing up for a much quieter season this year because of the coronavirus crisis. Brits normally make up most of the holidaymakers flocking to Magaluf and its raucous Punta Ballena party strip in the peak summer season months. But local tourism chiefs have predicted they could be outnumbered by other nationalities including Spaniards and Germans this yeara feared UK quarantine keeps them away.

story: NewsChildrens hospice backed by royal family shuts after £million coronavirus lossesEXCLUSIVE Sophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices, has been left “incredibly saddened” after the coronavirus pandemic forced it to close one of its two sitesShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA childrenaposs hospice backed by the Royal Family has been forced to close after Covid- blew a £million hole in its finances. Sophie, Countess of Wessex, patron of Shooting Star Children’s Hospices, has been left “incredibly saddened” after it shut one of two sites dedicated to helping  seriously ill kids. The charity, which has been visited by other senior royals including Prince Charles and Camilla, and the Duchess of Cambridge, offers emergency respite and end-of-le care. But a Mirror probe has discovered it is one of dozens of hospices, which rely on the public’s generosity, facing unprecedented hardship. Mass cancellations of fundraising events such as the London Marathon and the closure of high street charity shops have fuelled the crisis.Karen Sugarman, vice president of SSCH, which supports children in London and Surrey, said: “Covid- has had a devastating effect, like being run over by a massive steamroller. “Nobody could have been prepared for this. We are fighting with everything we have to be there for people who need us in their darkest hour.” Shooting Star was awarded £, in emergency government funding last month, but with services costing £, a day, Karen says it has “merely papered over the cracks”. She added: “The Government has been slow to react and there hasn’t been an adequate response.  “Sadly I don’t think we have ever been high enough on their agenda. “Charities around the world are suffering. We all have dferent needs but we are in this together.” The Mirror has been campaigning for the Government to double its funding to hospices to end the postcode lottery of hospice care, recruit more palliative care doctors and community nurses, and guarantee all terminally ill children receive end-of-le care. The closed facility, in Hampton, South West London, was visited by the Countess in February just weeks before the lockdown. Its ten child bedrooms and six family flats, normally full, will remain empty until funding is found. To raise awareness carers recorded a version of Miley Cyrus’ song The Climb, complete with sign language, which the singer plugged on Twitter. A Buckingham Palace source said the Countess “is closely following their situation and being kept regularly informed”. They added: “She was incredibly moved by a video they posted recently and she was incredibly sad to hear that they have had to close the Hampton hospice for now. “She is hugely passionate about the role they play in the children’s lives and she will continue to support them where she can in the coming months.”  The hospice has also been supported by music mogul Simon Cowell and Spandau Ballet frontman Tony Hadley, plus David Walliams. But with the situation desperate, Karen, who has been with the charity  years, raised £, this month by singing and playing the accordion live to her friends. She said: “I don’t play the accordion and I’m not a great singer but we are all doing what we can. “The Countess and our other supporters are with us as well and that means so much. We are in an unprecedented times and must raise money to keep the service going for children and families who rely on us.” She added: “We are extremely thankful for the rescue package but, for us and many others, this is merely papering over the cracks. “People assume we are funded by the NHS but... we are wholly reliant on the generosity of others.” Charles and Camilla officially opened the Hampton centre in , before Camilla invited some of the children to Clarence House to help decorate the Christmas tree. In , Kate – who is patron of East Anglia’s Children’s Hospices –also visited the charity at its former base in Middlesex.  As part of its emergency response to the pandemic, the Government promised £million in grants to support hospices. But insiders say it is not enough and the care and support needed by a quarter of a million people every year hangs in the balance. Pop star turned campaigner Hadley said: “We really rely on public and corporate donations, which sadly have decreased during the pandemic, as people face their own financial uncertainties. “I know this is a dficult time for many, but any money you can donate would be so appreciated.”

Aberdeenshire Council is considering making them capable of holding hundreds of coffins as part of measures to deal with the Covid-. The planning covers Scotlandaposs north east coast after local council bosses said cremation and burial services could be overwhelmed. Latest figures from National Records Scotland show that only  people have died in the region from coronavirus with , dying in Scotland. Philip McKay, head of roads, landscapes and waste services at the council, said at a virtual council meeting that initially the regionaposs funeral industry looked bleak from initial forecasts. Mr McKay said: As part of that modelling there were ideas similar to New Yorkaposs approach, that we may have to open what effectively would be strip lairs. story: NewsGrandad turns  three decades after heart transplant meant give five more yearsEddie Tierney, from Rhyl, in Wales, was  when he had a heart transplant op in  and surgeons warned him the organ may last only five yearsShareCommentsByPaul Byrne:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsEddie Tierney, from Wales, pictured dancing with his daughter  years ago " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA great-grandad has celebrated his th birthday more than three decades after a heart transplant. Eddie Tierney was  when he had the op in  – and surgeons warned him the organ may last only five years. But  years later he is still going strong and yesterday welcomed a new law which means everyone in England is assumed to be an organ donor, unless they opt out. Max and Keira’s Law is named after Max Johnson, , of Winsford, Cheshire, and his heart donor Keira Ball, nine, who died in a car accident near her home in Barnstaple, Devon, in . The Mirror campaigned for four years to bring it to the statute book. Eddie lives in Wales, where the opt-out system has been in place since . “It is a good idea as far I’m concerned,” said Eddie, who lives with his we Phyllis, , near Rhyl, Denbighshire. “It means there is more chance of people getting a heart transplant than there was when I had mine.” Eddie, a former cabinet maker who later ran a second-hand shop, fell ill with a flu virus which attacked his heart. “I went in with the flu and the next thing I was told I had six weeks to live,” he said.  After a spell in Glan Clwyd Hospital in nearby Bodelwyddan he received a transplant at Harefield Hospital in West London. The operation was performed by world famous surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub. Eddie said: “I was his rd heart ­transplant at Harefield. He told me when I had it done that I should get five years.” One of the young doctors who cared for him initially in North Wales later became the Tierney family’s local GP. Dr David Whyler phoned Eddie last week to say happy birthday. Eddie said: “He told me he could never believe that I would get to . I’m still here. To be still here  years on, it’s just remarkable. I just can’t believe it.” Eddie later discovered his heart donor was a -year-old woman. And although he never met her family, he said: “I’m so grateful to them.” He still enjoys road trips on his two motorcycles and added: “I’m looking forward to getting out on my bike when the lockdown ends.” Eddie, who has a son, Michael, a daughter, Debbie, four grandchildren and a three-month-old great-grandson, Caleb, had to scrap a birthday party planned last Friday.

Troy House in Monmouth originates from the th century and the Grade II listed four storey dream home comes complete with a theatre, chapel and two tennis courts. It was built for the family of the Duke of Beaufort, adding to an imposing portfolio of properties which also included Great Castle House in Monmouth and Badminton House in Gloucestershire. The estate was later converted into a convent school and then became a school, but as the condition of the buildings deteriorated the school moved locations in the s and the once grand manor has been left to rot.The , square-foot property has now been put up for auction, with a guide price of between £, and £, - but a look inside at just how dilapidated it has become suggests youaposll need far deeper pockets toit to its former glory.Listed by Allsop, it provides  bedrooms, four dormitories, a principalaposs flat, a staff flat, a caretakeraposs flat, a two storey hostel block, outbuildings and gargaing.The picturesque setting and grand exterior belie the true scale of the renovation job required, with photos of the interior showing floorboards and structures rotten through, with a huge clearance job needed to clear the abandoned school furniture. The description reads: The property is presented in a poor state of repair and requires extensive works of modernisation and refurbishment. The property may afford possible potential for redevelopment and or a number of alternative uses, subject to obtaining all necessary consents. If youaposre able to look beyond the current state of repair, the ultimate do-er upper does come with some incredible benefits, including sprawling land, original fittings and an estate that wouldnapost look out of place on Downton Abbey. Itaposs located a short journey from the historic market town of Monmouth, with both Cardf and Bristol city centres also accessible. With the Brecon Beacons National Park to the west and River Wye is to the east, you wonapost be short of idyllic viewsyou want a bit of a break from the DIY. In the North East, which is now the region with the highest number of daily cases being recorded, , new infections are logged every  hours.  While the falling infection numbers in London are heartening, the capital nor the country are by any means out of the woods.The Governmentaposs top advisory group has warned that the rate of coronavirus infection is rising and could be close to one.The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciessaid the UK reproduction number for the coronavirus is now between . and one, having risen from . and . two weeks ago.  If the reproduction numberis higher than one, then the rate of infection will rise across the UK. If it is lower than one, then the outbreak will shrink. The research was carried out by six research groups and suggested that cases in care homes and hospitals accounted for a greater proportion of cases than last week.

title: mcdonalds rush shows locked down
story: NewsFrom McDonalds and pubs to shops and buses - how UK is ing to normalityThe queues of cars full of punters hungry for their first McDonalds burgers and fries and months reveal Brits desperation for a taste of le before lockdownShareCommentsByRuki SayidConsumer Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMcDonalds in Chelmsford opens for drive through orders " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThere was little doubt of our hunger toto normality as cars queued outside McDonald’s drive-throughs hours before they reopened today. And as fast-food fans grabbed meals to go, there were plenty of other indicators that the country is getting back on the move... McDonaldaposs Burgers were back on the menu as McDonald’s pulled up the shutters at  drive-throughs across the South East. Despite the sites offering a limited menu, cars were bumper-to-bumper before opening time at am in queues not seen since the Boxing Day sales. Follow our live blog for the latest coronavirus news and updates The chain capped orders to £ per car and said it will close sitesthey became over-congested. McDonald’s said: “McDonald’s and its franchisees are working closely with local authorities and the police, and may determine it is necessary to close lanesqueues cause disruption at busier sites or put employees or customers at risk.” The giant aims to have all of its drive-throughs open by early June. Buses Bus operators First Bus, Stagecoach and Arriva have added extra services after limiting passenger numbers to % of capacity to help ensure social distancing.  First Bus said drivers will do a head count using a device on ticket machines, closing doors and setting off when % capacity is reached. Passengers who make it on will be asked to sit a safe distance apart. Dave Lynch, of parent company FirstGroup, said: “We have been working round the clock to find ways to innovate so we can ensure safe, socially distanced space.” Stagecoach and Arriva want commuters to wear masks and sit by a window on their own unless with a family member – and keep seats in front and behind free. Passengers paying with cash must have the exact fare, as drivers will not give change to reduce the risk of infection. The Confederation of Passenger Transport said it was keeping people up to date “on how they can play their part to keep the bus network safe”.  A Transport Focus poll revealed % would not travel unless social distancing was in place – up from % two weeks ago. And % would not be happy to use public transport unless passengers had to wear face masks – up from %. Shops Poundland re-opened  stores yesterday, taking the total trading to  this week. Furniture Village has re-opened six sites while the remaining  will be ready for trading on Saturday. And John Lewis has outlined plans to get ready for shoppers as it anticipates a green light. Perspex screens have been fitted at checkouts and information desks. Stores with large car parks are likely to open first and private buses may ferry staff to workpublic transport is an issue.  Clothes tried on but not bought will be quarantined before ing to rails and floors will get m spacing stickers.But the firm may have to halt consultations on baby goods, fashion and technology until social distancing is axed.Operations chief Andrew Murphy said: “We want to be safe – not fast.” Pubs Pubs bolstered their case to reopen on July  with new proposals to satisfy the Government that they can safely serve food and drink. Trade body UK Hospitality said plans include no drinking at the bar, no salt and pepper or sauces on tables, and cutlery brought to diners with their food in table service only.  Roped off areas, restrictions on kids’ playgrounds and patrolled smoking areas are also on the cards. UKH chief Kate Nicholls said the draft guidelines have been shared with governments in England, Scotland and Wales. She added: “We hope the guidelines will help businesses draw up plans based on their premises, ensuring safety is at the forefront when the right time comes to reopen.”  Kick-off pm Sat... on the telly Football fans without Sky or BT Sport could be able to watch live matches for free at pm on Saturdays, Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden suggested. Broadcasters have previously been banned from screening fixtures at that time amid fears fans would watch on TV rather than attend games. But matches are due to take place behind closed doors when the season resumes. Mr Dowden said: “I think that creates an opportunity for us to be able to get some sport, some Premier League, free-to-air.” He added: “Those discussions are ongoing.”  Mr Dowden also offered hope for UK staycations, saying he’d “love to get the tourism sector up as quickly as we possibly can”. Mayorsapos plea for homeless Mayors have urged the Government to seize a “once in a generation” chance to tackle rough sleeping after the crisis. Labour leaders in Manchester, Liverpool, London, Sheffield and North Tyne want ministers to deliver a new funding package. During the pandemic more than , rough sleepers have been offered emergency digs.  But the initial funding package is due to run out within weeks and ministers say getting them in longer-term accommodation is up to skint local authorities. Councils say extra funding to tackle Covid- is too little. Labour leader Keir Starmer backed a joint statement by the mayors, which said: “When this crisis is over, we cannotto business as usual.” Boris boosts gongs hope Boris Johnson has given the clearest hint yet that he will back a medal for our NHS heroes. The PM said this year’s June honours announcement will be delayed to autumn so it can recognise the contribution of those fighting Covid-. In a written statement to Parliament, he said: “The Government is clear there will be opportunities to mark the contributions of so many – but at the appropriate time.” It was the latest boost for the Mirror’s Give NHS Heroes a Medal campaign and came after Captain Tom Moore, , was given a knighthood for raising £million for the NHS. Brits looking at holidays abroad as restrictions lt Bookings for holidays to countries that have lted travel restrictions spiked this week, in a sign the nation is getting back on its feet. Portugal and Greece have eased their lockdowns and Spain plans to end its own next month. Experts believe millions of Brits are banking on a September getaway. Hays Travel co-founder Irene Hays said: “At the moment they are booking for September. Without a doubt, the British people are ready for a holiday.”

title: nations favourite sandwich been named
story: NewsNations favourite sandwich has been confirmed - and its a bacon buttyA poll of , adults were asked what their favourite sarnies with a bacon butty beating cheese and pickle, beef and horseradish, and chicken and bacon to the top spotShareCommentsByLorraine King:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe nations favourite sandwich is a bacon butty " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe bacon butty has been named the nationaposs best loved sandwich - with egg and cress sneaking into the top ten. A poll of , adults saw the British staple of fried or grilled bacon sandwiched between two chunky slices of bread come out on top. Other popular fillings include cheese and pickle, chicken and bacon, and even a filling of crisps. The results show a sht in tastes, with a similar study from  seeing a plain cheese sandwich top the chart. This was followed by ham and cheese - which has now slipped to sixth place - with the nation favouring sausage, and egg mayonnaise two years on.  It also emerged that when it comes to preparing the perfect sandwich, aposwhite, medium sliced bread with the crusts left on and cut into squaresapos, is the top choice. A spokesman for Warburtons, which commissioned the  and  studies, said: However you prepare it, or whatever you fill it with, thereaposs something that canapost be beaten about a good old British sandwich. Itaposs interesting to see bacon top the list as weaposre all craving comforting, simple and hearty meals as social distancing continues. Itaposs also great to see Brits get more creative in the kitchen with jam and cheese, and even peanut butter and marmalade being used in the nationaposs sandwiches.  The combinations are endless so it comes as no surprise that bread is still one of the nationaposs favourite go-tos. The study also found itaposs not just sandwiches being enjoyed more by the nation, as a third of adults are eating more toasties now than they did before the lockdown, with cheese the most popular filling. And among the best loved condiments to enjoy with sandwiches were pickle , ketchupand mayonnaise . Others choose to spice up their sarnie with a splash of sriracha , a drop of tabascoor a spread of English mustard .  It also emerged almost half of those polled are eating more bread, while a third are enjoying more toast since the start of lockdown. The average person will enjoy four sandwiches and two toasties during a typical week - but a fth are currently tucking into more than seven sandwiches in a seven-day period. As a result, the average household is getting through two loaves of bread a week - with a quarter consuming more than three loaves in that time. Nearly a third Brits said the reason theyaposve had more bread is because they arenapost buying as many meals away from home, and  per cent put it down to having lots of other food in the house which goes well with it. Lunch is still the most popular time to enjoy a sarnie or toastie with  per cent doing so, while a quarter of Brits frequently indulge by snacking on a sandwich.  More than a third actually prefer sandwiches for lunch over a hot meal, and  per cent would even struggle to go a day without enjoying a slice of bread. However, people are no longer creatures of habit as  per cent of those polled, via OnePoll, try to alternate their sandwich fillings, and one in  have been more experimental with fillings during lockdown. Some of the strange and unusual creations put together by the UK were also revealed with one respondent admitting to enjoying a chocolate spread and salami sandwich. Another confessed to eating a chocolate biscuit sandwich, with corned beef and peanut butter also among the inventive combinations.

story: NewsSleeping with your fan on could be seriously damaging your health - what to do insteadLots of us have given in and started leaving our fan on overnight in a desperate bid to get some sleep, but some people need to be carefulShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  JUL Updated:,  MAY NewsIs it too hot for you to sleep  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. But while we love the heat in the day, itaposs a very, very dferent story when weaposre trying to get a good nightaposs kip. As well as opening every window in the house, many people have been keeping their fans on overnight in a desperate bid to keep cool. And according to the experts, for most of us this is actually the right thing to doyou want a good night sleep. This can be bad news for people with allergies, asthma and hayfever. The dry air can also dry out our skin, so itaposs important to keep moisturising. It can also cause dry eyes which can make them irritable, especiallyyou wear contact lenses. If youaposre looking for an alternative there are a few other things you can try.  To cool down a room, try hanging a wet sheet in front of an open window. Bizarre, but it works. Closing the curtains during the day will also keep your room cooler, which will make it much nicer when it comes to bedtime. The right sheets are also key when it comes to keeping cool. Avoid satin and silk and stick to cooler linen and cotton sheets. Many people are also worried about how electricity their fan uses, and how much it costs to have it on all night. Experts from This Is Money say the answer to this depends on several factors - the kind of fan you have and the amount of energy it uses.
