title: borders-mp-reveals-rejected-bid-help-farmers
story: A BORDERS politician has defended himself after rejecting an opportunity to ban imports of low quality meat.John Lamont MP was among the Westminster parliamentarians who turned down an attempt to protect food standards last week.But Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, says the UK Government will ensure British farmers are not hurt by future trade deals.He said: ldquoCritically, we will maintain our import standards, which include the ban on chlorine-washed chicken and hormone-injected beef.Some farming figures criticised politicians for failing to back Neil Parish MPrsquos amendment to the Agriculture Bill in the House of Commons on May .Mr Parish said the amendment aimed to make sure food imports are produced to the equivalent standards upheld in the UK.NFU Scotlandrsquos director of policy Jonnie Hall said it was ldquodeeply disappointing that the amendment lost by  votes.Mr Lamont told the Border he was ldquounable to support all of the amendments.The member for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk added: ldquoThe government has made it clear that no UK import standards will be diminished as part of any free trade agreement.ldquoWe will also not undermine our high domestic environmental protection, animal welfare and food safety standards by ensuring in any agreement British farmers are always able to compete.ldquoI know that the UK Government is working very closely with industry figures to get the best trade deal that will allow Scottish farming to flourish.The Agriculture Bill passed its third reading in the House of Commons and will now be considered by the House of Lords.

title: happened-councils-first-virtual-meeting
story: TODAYsaw an unusual, yet historic, occasion for Scottish Borders Councilas it held its first virtual committee meeting since lockdown began.A total of nine councillors participated in the meeting of the planning and building standardscommittee, which gave approval for a houseto be built in Newstead.Chairman Tom Miers, a Conservative representative for Leaderdale and Melrose, said the meeting "went well given the circumstances".Journalists were allowed to view proceedings, conducted through Microsoft Teams, after the council made a U-turn on its original decision to ban the press.Mr Miers said: "Its not as good as meeting face to face. I would prefer to be able to have public input into the meetings, which is hard to do remotely."Also, it may be harder to have detailed technical discussion on matters of process in this medium at future meetings."Wersquoll see, and wersquoll adapt as necessary to make it as good as possible."We were able to conduct a full discussion of the issues and we heard a range of views from dferent councillors. So the PBS committee fulfilled its remit properly."Dreaded technical dficulties reared their head on several occasions, however ndash some councillors struggled with muting and un-muting their microphones.After they backed an application to build a house, Mr Miers reminded elected members that feedback was welcome on how the meeting went.As affairs drew to a close, conversation turned to facial hair grown since the last face-to-face meeting on March .One officer said his new beard "wont be lasting long".JS Crawford Farming Partnership has won permission to build a property on the corner of Main Street and Eddy Road.

title: borders-pupils-achieve-first-ever-higher-enterprise
story: BORDERS students are among the first in the country to gain a Higher in enterprise.Six pupils from Earlston High School completed Young Enterprise Scotlands Company Programme, despite the title: scotlands-schools-set-return-august-11-part-time-phased-re-opening
story: SCHOOLS in Scotland are set for a phasedfrom August , according to reports.The proposals would mean some teachers wouldto work in June in preparation, with childrens "blended" learning involving spending half their time in the classroom, and half at home.The Daily Record revealed the plans reportedly put together by Education Secretary John Swinney.It comes after Boris Johnson revelaed plans to reopenschools for some pupils in England by June .Some pupils starting primary and secondary, according to the paper, will be allowed to access schools next month.One senior education source told the Recordsaid: ldquoTrying to reopen schools in a pandemic was always going to be a big challenge but lots of effort has gone into this plan.ldquoIt is obviously dependent on the science butthe scientic advice is positive then this plan can be implemented and children will be able toto school safely.Its reported that the Education Recovery Groupm chaired by Swinney, has been working on the plan to reopen schools on August .Biut that is dependent on scientic advice, an effective "test, trace and isolate" stategy and enough PPE Stocks for staff.A Scottish Government spokesperson told the RecordldquoThursdayrsquos route-map will also set out our up to date assessment at that point of a phasedto school, as guided by the considerations of the Education Recovery Group.

title: raf-reveals-many-planes-seen-coronavirus-lockdown
story: Several largemilitary aeroplanes have been spotted over Scottish cities in recent weeks.And out in the countryside, several people have reported hearing jets regualarlyscreaming through the skies late at night.Now the RAF has spoken out to reassure the public that there is nothing sinister taking place and reveal the real reason why its aircraft have been seen across Scotland.The most noticeable planes to have been spotted recently launched from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.These large aircraft have been observed circling Glasgow as well as making brief landings during "touch and go" manoeuvres designed to practice these tricky and sometimes risky touchdowns.In wartime, some planes have to make landings on rough terrain, so its imperative that pilots are as well-practised as possible." alt"Border : This is an Airbus AM Atlas, the type of airfact seen over Glasgow in recent weeks " class"editor-image"This is an Airbus AM Atlas, the type of airfact seen over Glasgow in recent weeks A spokesman for RAF Lossiemouth told The Herald:"Due to the lockdown, the public have become more aware and interested in these activities."To be clear, these were all occurring prior to the pandemic. But a lack of civil aviation now makes them stand out more."Many of the larger aircraft based out of RAF Brize Norton, such as the C- Hercules, AM Atlas, A-MRTT Voyager, and C- Globemaster regularly fly on essential, but routine training missions around the United Kingdom."The C- and A in particular fly quite low-level profiles, and on operations they will be used to land in areas where there are not established runway surfaces."This can include landing on beaches, for example."The quiet skies have made it easier to spot military planes, which can sometimes be identied and followed using apps like FlightRadar.Occasionally, the military planes have been observed performing strange-looking manoeuvres such as flying around in circles .The RAF said these odd flight patterns have a clear explanation: the aircraft were involved in mid-air refuelling.For the last three weeks RAF Lossiemouth has been involved in night flying exercise which concluded on Friday, May  involving Typhoon jets."During our night flying window, we launched our first set of sorties around ," the spokesman added."This meant we were able to generate two or three training serials a day ndash two in daylight, and one in low-light conditions."The Typhoon is a multi-role aircraft, which means itrsquos able to conduct a number of dferent missions while in the air air-to-air and air-to-ground manoeuvres to name two."To enable our Typhoons to stay on task for longer and travel larger distances, we are often supported by Voyagers ndash the RAFrsquos air-to-air refuelling aircraft based at RAF Brize Norton.,params: .push"These Voyager aircraft will fly lsquoracetracks in the skyrsquo, and are usually visible on flight tracking websites which pick up ADS-B."In the United Kingdom, live-armed Typhoons are on "constant standby to react against unidentied aircraft approaching UK airspace as well as aircraft that are operating in an unusual manner, which may pose a threat".Typhoons are often scrambled on "Quick Reaction Alert" missions to intercept planes which enter British airspace"Our last intercept was against two Bear-F ndash Russian Maritime Patrol Aircraft on April ," the spokesman said."Additionally the Typhoon Force are involved in NATO Air Policing missions, such as Op AZOTIZE in Lithuania where  Squadron deployed a few weeks ago."Typhoons have also been involved in strikes against Daesh."A Typhoon jetIf youre worried by the sudden appearance of a military aeroplane, you can generally find out what its up to by visiting offical Twitter accounts or the RAF website."The RAF has always been open about its operations and exercises," the spokesman continued."With the public now spending more time at home, many have taken to their gardens or spent more time on their phones."They have also become more acutely aware of the noises above their houses, and wersquove seen a signicant increase in interest in routine, but essential flying as a result."When we do launch Quick Reaction Alert, wherever possible we publish information as to who we intercepted, what the aircraft were doing, why the interception was carried out, roughly where it all happened, and we aim to answer as many questions we can whilst maintaining operational security."Itrsquos vital that the public understand why this activity is essential to the defence of the United Kingdom."

title: nicola-sturgeon-pledges-help-selkirk-ovo-workers
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has addressed the Scottish Parliament about the closure of a Borders office employing  workers.As reported yesterday, OVO Energy has revealed it will close its Selkirk site.At Holyrood today , Ms Sturgeon said: "I deeply regret the announcement from OVO Energy, which has a huge impact in Selkirk."OVO has declined to state how many jobs losses are likely in the Borders, with employees being invited to apply for voluntary redundancy first.The First Ministers comments came after a question from Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton, a Conservative member.Mrs Hamilton said: "These job losses are devastating for a fragile rural economy like the Scottish Borders and the young people, in particular, will be affected acutely."She added: "Can I ask the First Minister what the Scottish Governments response is to these job losses "And in the pandemic lockdown, will the PACE [redundancy] services be operating as normal to support these devastating job losses "In reply, Ms Sturgeon said: "We will, through Scottish Enterprise, continue to engage with this company [OVO] ndash and any company in a similar situation ndash to considerthere are any actions we can take to prevent or mitigate redundancies and well also make sure that PACE [redundancy support] is operational."

title: lockdown-highlights-critical-role-plants-charles-tells-virtual-chelsea
story: The coronavirus lockdown has highlighted the ldquocritical role plants play in health and wellbeing, the Prince of Wales has said in a message for the virtual Cha Flower Show.Many people have reconnected with nature at home, gained a heightened appreciation of their local green spaces and discovered a new love of gardening and food production, Charles said.The heir to the throne, who is a long-time advocate of climate action, also said that healthy plants and trees are ldquovitally important in mitigating climate change by storing carbon.But just as the world has realised the importance of plants, ldquowe have managed to engineer a global plant health crisis, he warned.And he urged visitors to the online Cha Flower Show to take simple actions themselves to prevent the spread of plant pests and diseases.He said: ldquoIn recent weeks the coronavirus lockdown has highlighted the critical role plants play in our own health and wellbeing and quite a few of us will have had the opportunity to reconnect with nature at home.ldquoI know many people have discovered a heightened appreciation for their local green space and a new-found love for gardening and food produce, which he said is a ldquowelcome outcome from this desperate situation.ldquoI also know Irsquom not alone in feeling plants and trees play an utterly valuable and indispensable role in our lives.ldquoAnd, in the midst of this tragic health crisis, itrsquos easy to forget the worsening climate crisis, the catastrophic effects of which have been dramatically felt in recent months, with floods and fires wreaking havoc on communities around the globe.In the online video message, he said many governments had unveiled plans for tree planting and restoring wetlands to store carbon emissions.ldquoFrom every angle plants play an absolutely vital role in our existence, but the ultimate irony is, just as we are realising this, we have also managed to engineer a global plant health crisis, he said.He pointed to the loss of millions of elm trees, the spread of ash dieback, increasing awareness of threats to oaks and xylella threatening herbaceous plants.And he said: ldquoOur current situation shows just how quickly diseases and pathogens of all types are spread around the planet due to the hyper-connected nature of todayrsquos world, and with such tragic effect.Speaking during the international year of plant health, he said greater caution and vigilance are needed to ensure pests and diseases do not spread.And gardeners can take their own actions to protect plant le, he added.These include cleaning their tools, buying plants from reputable British growers and which have ideally been grown here, resisting the urge to buy plants while travelling abroad, and reporting anything unusual in their own garden.ndash Charlesrsquos video message forms part of the virtual Cha Flower Show, taking place online this week in place of the physical event which was title: welsh-government-defends-testing-policy-referral-human-rights-watchdog
story: The Welsh Government has defended its policy on coronavirus testing in care homes after it was reported to the human rights watchdog.The Older Peoplersquos Commissioner for Wales reported the Welsh Government to the Equality and Human Rights Commissionover delays to testing in care homes.But Walesrsquos health minister Vaughan Gething said that the advice and evidence was that there ldquowasnrsquot a value in testing people who were not symptomatic.It comes after the EHRC said last week that it was ldquodeeply concerned about breaches of older peoplersquos human rights across the UK during the pandemic."Elderly people are not second class citizens, they are entitled to the same rights that everyone  in society is entitled to." @EHRCChairspeaking on tonights @ChannelNews.Read about how were responding to COVID- here ## https:t.co zIWJSWTApic qnHIBvOmdash EHRCMay , The watchdog said it was considering the use of all our powers to protect their rights both now and following the pandemic.Ruth Coombs, EHRC head of Wales, on Tuesday said it was working with the Older Peoplersquos Commissioner and other partners representing the interests of older people.She added: ldquoWe remain deeply concerned about serious potential breaches of older peoplersquos human rights during this pandemic.ldquoThe slow response by Welsh Government to testing residents and staff in care homes, discharge of Covid- positive older people from hospital into care homes, examples of inappropriate blanket healthcare decisions on issues such as Do Not Attempt Resuscitation notices, and the lack of sufficient PPE for care workers have contributed to considerable distress, lack of confidence that their rights will be protected and ultimately to loss of le.ldquoWe are working closely with the Older Peoplersquos Commissioner and other partners representing the interests of older people, and are considering the use of all our powers to protect their rights now and following the coronavirus pandemic.The Older Peoplersquos Commissioner for Wales Helena Herklots told BBC Radio Wales that comprehensive testing for Covid- in care homes was ldquotoo slow.ldquoVery early on in this pandemic older people were being pushed to sign do not attempt CPR notices, she added.ldquoFirst and foremost what should have been done is looking at how to protect our most vulnerable citizens and older people.ldquoI donrsquot believe that has had the focus it needs.ldquoThe Equality and Human Rights Commission should do an inquiry into what has happened. title: yacht-club-takes-measures-help-stay-afloat
story: The yachts should have been craned into the harbour at the start of April and the committee had an ldquoanxious pre-season discussion to figure out safe ways to continue activities as the coronavirus crisis started to unfold.After the full lockdown, with the boats still on dry land, members have been using Skype on a near weekly basis to plan how to keep the club thriving for the foreseeable and long-term future.Former commodore Mark McClelland has urged members to take part in an online sailing race game called Virtual Regatta.One club member will be asked to take part in a Virtual Regatta e-championship against players from other Scottish clubs and then go on to a UK-wide competition.While playing the game, Fisherrow Yacht Clubparticipants also take part in a virtual Friday Night Bar get-together, enjoying a tipple in their own homes while connected to other participants through Zoom.One of the biggest losses to the club programme is the start-of-the season event called Discover Sailing, formerly known as Push the Boat Out, which was due to take place this Saturday, May .Inez Visser, club spokesperson, said: ldquoIt should have been an open day for non-members to try sailing and to look around the facilities in the club premises.ldquoDiscover Sailing has been the most important means to recruit new members in the last few years.ldquoFYC hopes to be able to recreate something similar later in the summer while taking into account necessary hygiene requirements.She explained: ldquoMany FYC members can sail their dinghies or yachts solo or with family members so, from that aspect, sailing can resume as soon as is permitted.ldquoIn addition,local members can come to the beach already dressed to go out on the water, this would free up space in the changing facilities for those who travel from further away.ldquoCurrently, the biggest challenge is figuring out a way to crew the club safety and race committee power boats without breach of the contamination guidelines.ldquoHowever, many resourceful solutions have been devised to protect people from contamination so FYC is hopeful a solution for watersports can be found soon.She added: ldquoWhile not sailing, the committee has been looking at research information published by the sailing umbrella body, Royal Yachting Association , which has analysed age demographics and water participation in general in the last few years.ldquoUsing the information from RYA, the club is looking forward to how its current activities and club facilities, especially club-owned boats, can be dferently managed to suit the needs of the next generation of sailors.ldquoThis includes not only Generations X, Y and Z, but also third age sailors, as the research highlighted that sailing is well suited to older people because the physical demands are not as great as many other sports.ldquoAt this time, FYC is ever mindful that the club premises are a resource, not only for the sailing club, title: veteran-musicians-mark-ve-day-doorsteps
story: Alastair Knowles BEM played the lsquoLast Postrsquo on the bugle from the front door of his Stoneyhill home and pipe major Stewart Braby performed lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at the Mall near his house in Inveresk Road last Friday.Mr Knowles said he was asked by Iain Clark, from Musselburgh, a Depute Lieutenant of East Lothian, to mark the end of the two -minute silence at am that day by ringing the bell at Northesk Church in Musselburgh, which he duly did.Mr Knowles also heard from Bruno Peek, VE Day  Pageant Master, who was keen to keep as much of the national programme going as possible amidst the coronavirus pandemic.The events were arranged to mark the th anniversary of Victory in Europe Day ndash the day celebrating the formal acceptance by the Allies of the Nazisrsquo unconditional surrender of their armed forces, on Tuesday,  May , marking the end of the Second World War in Europe.Buglers and trumpeters were still urged to sound the lsquoLast Postrsquo, as planned, at .pm, and pipers to play lsquoBattlersquos Orsquoerrsquo at pm.Mr Knowles followed his uncle into the Boysrsquo Brigade in the mid-s.Since then he has become a key part of the group, becoming a bugler and leading drummer in the Penicuik and Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band.He was Town Champion at the  Riding of the Marches in Musselburgh, before being appointed chairman of the  event.He is also a former president of the Old Musselburgh Club.He received the BEM for services to the community in Musselburgh.Mr Braby, pipe major with the Penicuik  Musselburgh Boysrsquo Brigade Pipe Band, is also pipe major of the massed bands at the Boysrsquo Brigade Beating Retreat at Edinburgh Castle.Mr Knowles said: ldquoLater in the evening my we Lily and I, as our daily exercise outing, took a walk to Northesk, where the third member of the church,Lorraine McBrearty, added her contribution with the singing of lsquoWersquoll Meet Againrsquo only yards from her home on Bridge Street at pm.He added: ldquoIt was a busy but fulfilling day.

title: tributes-paid-caring-gran
story: Irene Grant spent last Friday saying farewell to her mother Mary Jane Gouldingat a funeral parlour before ing for afternoon tea in the garden of her home on Rope Walk, Prestonpans.She was preparing to spend the day alone but Musselburghrsquos Yarnbombers group ndash famous for their wool-based community art displays ndash had arranged to leave lsquoJock and Jeannie,rsquo a knitted lsquocouplersquo, who were due to have pride of place at a street party at Musselburghrsquos Brunton Hall, outside her home.The public event to celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day was cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic but Irene, who was brought up in Musselburgh, was determined to mark the occasion the way her -year-old mum would have wanted.Irene went to her doorstep at am to observe the nationrsquos twominute silence before she and her neighbours had afternoon tea in their own gardens as well as a social distance singalong featuring an emotional rendition of lsquoWersquoll Meet Again.Irene, a member of the yarnbombers, decorated her garden with knitted cakes, a lsquogrow your own vegetablesrsquo display and put up bunting ndash in keeping with the grouprsquos tradition of brightening up Musselburgh with dferent knitted displays since the Riding of the Marches in .A founder member of Musselburghrsquos Clark Concert Party, she said: ldquoI was at the undertaker making arrangements for mum and came home to Jock and Jeannie sitting on my steps. It was an amazing surprise ndash although I got the fright of my le. You have no idea how much it cheered me up and gave me a much needed laugh. My friends in the Yarnbombers decided I needed company. I was determined to go ahead with a wee party, although I live on my own and have no one to celebrate with. Mum was in a nursing home and the family had not seen her for eight weeks nor were we permitted to be with her at the end.Mary, who was resident at Drummond Grange Nursing Home at Lasswade, took a ldquosevere decline two weeks before her death.Irene said: ldquoShe was not eating or drinking. Everyone thought she had lsquoturned her back to the wallrsquo with being in isolation. Her attending doctor thought she would test her for Covid and we got the news that it was positive. Mum had shown no symptoms whatsoever. She died on Sunday, May .Mary was born in Nova Scotia, Canada, in March , where her parents George and Mary Grahamhad emigrated to after her father was laid off during the General Strike of .They ed to Prestonpans four years later and Mary, her two sisters and three brothers, enjoyed ldquoan extremely happy childhood at their home in Nethershot.Her dad was a miner at Prestongrange colliery all his working le.Mary married her husband Jim Goulding on March , , at Newcraighall Church, and Irene and her sister Janice had a happy childhood growing up at Galt Crescent in Musselburgh.Mary worked as a carer home help until her retirement.After she and Jim orced, she moved to South Street where she lived for a few years before moving to amenity housing on Hercus Loan.She was diagnosed with vascular dementia in  and, in , went into care, latterly becoming a resident at Drummond Grange.Irene said: ldquoThis became her home and our family will never be able to thank the staff there enough for the love and care they showed her, particularly in these past weeks. One observation about the staff came from the undertaker who said lsquothey had dressed your mum in her Sunday best and she looked gorgeousrsquo.She added: ldquoWe cannot be sad that mum has gone because of the torment her mind was in for so long but we are all devastated with the circumstances in which she went ndash not seeing any of us for so long. For the first time in any of our lives, we missed being with her on her birthday and on Motherrsquos Day. It is such a tragic way to end a long fruitful le. She was so caring to everyone and had a wicked sense of humour which transcended the generations.A spokesperson for the nursing home said: ldquoWe would like to extend our deepest condolences to the family and friends who have lost a loved one in this awful pandemic. Mary was a much loved member of the community who treated everyone with kindness and respect, and will be dearly missed.Mary had bequeathed her body to medical science but this cannot happen in the current circumstances, so her funeral took place at Seafield Crematorium on Wednesday, which was attended by her immediate family.She is survived by her daughters Irene and Janice, four grandchildren, her sisters Isobel and Georgie, and many friends particularly Faye and Rod Gibson.The family have set up The Mary Goulding Celebration Fund to raise money for Alzheimer Scotland.To donate go to https:marygoulding.muchloved

title: covid-19-testing-centre-opening-former-power-station-site
story: The drive-through centre will be operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve unitsin Scotland and will carry out tests on key workers from tomorrowto Monday with plans toagain in two weeksrsquo time.East Lothian Council confirmed it had made the site available as part of the UKGovernmentrsquos Covid- testing programme.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre since the start of April.The Cockenzie site, bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, is currently being marketed for economic investment.In preparation of the appointment-only testing unitrsquos opening, signs and cones have been put in place to direct drivers.The centre will re-open on Saturday, May , through to Monday, June , and is providing back-up support to a main testing centre at EdinburghAirport.Key workers who have symptoms, or have a member of their household displaying symptoms, can self-refer to the site through the UK Governmentrsquos online portal.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site while the facility is closed.The council said it expects the unit to operate as a self-contained, drivethrough facility.People will remain in their vehicle while being tested.It is not known how many tests can be carried out at the site each day.Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel.ldquoThis facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-. East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move to open the centre at Cockenzie.He said: ldquoI have been calling on the Scottish Government to follow the World Health Organisationrsquos advice and ramp up the amount of testing we are doing for over a month now, so I welcome this new centre in Cockenzie and hope it will mean local key workers do not have to travel so far to access a test.ldquoA signicant increase in testing capacity will be essentialthe Scottish Governmentrsquos plans for testing, tracing and isolating are to be successful and this centre will contribute to the expansion needed.The move was also welcomed by local community councils.Bryan Hickman, chairperson of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased that the site is being used for a testing unit. It seems very suitable and hopefully it will help in getting this terrible virus under control.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoThe former power station site at Preston Links is an ideal location for a Covid testing site for East Lothian. It is remote enough from local communities with plenty of space to ensure government distancing regulations are maintained.The drive-through testing centres are available to people who live less than  minutes drive from them and are in addition to NHS Scotland testing.Scottish Government guidelines on who can apply for a test at the UK Government mobile testing centres are on their website.For a full list of those eligible to go bit.ly csBii Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via the self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stationrsquos famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September , two years after it had closed.

title: tims-tales-bogey-bogie-boogie-bug
story: IS IT A bogey, a bogie, or a boogie or maybe just a bug.Irsquoll be honest, I have very little idea of what Irsquom doing but in this time of lockdown, one of the tasks assigned to me by my children has been to make a go-cart.Well, my kids werenrsquot initially sure what a go-cart was. Their first request had been to buy a large toy car theyrsquod seen in some YouTube video, filmed by a wealthy family.You can picture the discussion after that. But thatrsquos when the alternative idea came to me.ldquoWell we could make a bogey cart, I said.Laughter at that expression followed of course, but I was sure I had the name right.It was from my childhood, so I Googled it and showed them what I meant, and they immediately agreed.Then I thought ldquowhat have I done  as I had no idea how to make one!I do have vague recollections of making semi-lethal bogey carts when I was wee using wheels from discarded prams and boxes or planks of wood. I still have a scar on my right knee from a bogey crash.If I could do it in my childhood, surely I could build one now I reasoned. Irsquom not very skilled at these things, but maybe thatrsquos because I havenrsquot tried.Besides, I had the expectations of my children to meet, and so I took on the challenge.It seemed to be a good lockdown activity. The first problem was the lack of materials. I recall a fish box was the best to use, and sturdy pram wheels but, during the lockdown especially, these items are not so easy to acquire.A friend kindly gave me a pallet, and I searched YouTube for advice. My heart began to sink.The videos were all made by people with workshops, tools and carpentry skills I lack. Their fancy-looking perfectly made carts just raised my childrenrsquos hopes.ldquoYea dad, one like that.I could feel my manhood was at stake.My daughter looked at me sympathetically and said: ldquoI know yoursquore busy with other things as well dad.So she gave me a generous five days to construct it.I managed to scavenge some wheels from a toy pram, helped again by a friend, and stood looking at the raw materials, trying to make a design in my imagination.I knew what a bogey cart was supposed to look like, but how to make something with the materials I had seemed a huge challenge.I set to work. I sawed and hammered, and made a good impression of looking like I knew what I was doing.But design challenges, in particular how to fit the wheels I had, which were on a frame, meant that the concept needed refined, and reduced in size.My daughter watched as I stood looking confused then determined then confused again.ldquoI overheard her asking her mum, lsquodo you think dad knows what he is doing rsquoSo I enlisted my childrenrsquos help, sawing and hammering together. At least this way we could all share in the glory, or shame, of the final product!At the time of writing I still have three days left to complete the task. In two days I have managed to make what I have euphemistically called ldquoa prototype a completely new concept in home-made go carts.It looks unsafe just now, but I must emphasise it is unfinished but the basic idea is there. I just hope BMW donrsquot steal the concept!The kids have named it the ldquobug, because itrsquos so small, and, well, looks like a bug!ldquoItrsquos a new kind of cart, a bug-cart! proclaimed my boy.I have three days to find a way to make this bug ldquofly safely.The lockdown is taking its toll on many families but the extra time it is giving some of us with family is one of the benefits. Finding creative activities to do during this time isnrsquot always easy.My kids have become hooked on screen activities which normally wersquod restrict. But these are not normal times, and I think parents need to give ourselves some slack and not worry too much. But there is a sense that this time has grounded many of us in simple meaning.Many of us are sharing skills, like baking, cooking, making things, learning activities, which before we often had little time to do together. But also rediscovering lost skills, or learning new ones by necessity, and making do with what we have like starting off making a bogie cart and ending with a ldquobug.The truth is, of course, itrsquos the quality of the time spent together as much as the quality of the final product that is important. Well, that will certainly be my story when the final version is unveiled!Itrsquos such a time of contradictory emotions I long for the end of the lockdown and the separation from other loved ones, and the loss and anxiety it means.But having this time to fill with meaning also feels like a huge privilege a kind of bittersweet liberation of my time.I have guilt about this, and like others, Irsquom trying to help out to compensate.But let us never forget that this time, and our safety, is made possible by the essential workers who are hard at work, keeping society going at such a dangerous time, and saving lives.Their skills and contributions have so often been taken for granted and unacknowledged.It has brought into sharp focus the  notion that low pay equates with ldquolow skilled work.The reality is that many who are low paid are, in fact, highly skilled and, as we are discovering, the most essential workers.I hope one of the legacies of this time will be a real recognition of the vital skills of many low paid workers, by valuing their work, both with status and proper pay.Letrsquos build statues to essential workers, instead of politicians and generals, and express gratitude for their contribution.And commit to being part of the change afterwards that will make this happen.Such were my thoughts as I assembled the ldquobug ndash my makesht haphazard invention of our lockdown time. I hope I will complete it by the deadline.In my area of East Lothian there is a community Facebook page where we can share our stories from this historic period.The ldquobug will be part of my contribution.We will all have our dferent lockdown legacies and stories to remember and record for posterity. What is yours Already safety rules for the bug are being set by my children. Number one rule: dad must never sit on it, but he can pull it.The term rod for my own back comes to mind.

title: seventy-years-since-147-whales-stranded-thorntonloch-sands
story: This was a major environmental disaster, particularly as the council had to develop plans to remove the whales from the beach.Word soon spread across East Lothian and beyond, and the scene attracted large crowds of people.In , Dr Herring told the Courier: ldquoWhile this was a tragedy for the whales, which all died or were shot by the RSPCA, it can also be seen as a social occasion where many people gathered.ldquoI interviewed a number of those who went to see the whales and what they told me reveals much about society in , and how dferent it was to today.The headlines in the Haddingtonshire Courier ndash as the paper was then called ndash of May , , were: WHALES STRANDED NEAR DUNBAR, THORNTONLOCH BEACH SCENES, DISPOSAL OF CARCASES.The paper reported: ldquoThousands of sightseers from the Lothians and the North of England visited Thorntonloch Bay on Sunday, to view the  whales which stranded on the beach about .am the previous day.ldquoThe traffic on the roads leading to Thorntonloch was the heaviest seen in East Lothian for many years, hundreds of vehicles, including specially chartered buses, being parked on the highway and the side roads from Skateraw to Dunglass Bridge, a distance of about two and a half miles.This amount of traffic was unheard of in , as few people had access to a car and a very small minority owned one.In his book, Dr Herring quotes two men who were boys at the time and who told the author that seeing all the cars was even more exciting than seeing the whales.It will seem strange to younger people today that, in , most of the population of Britain saw travelling in a car as something you did when going to a wedding or a funeral.Dr Herring was given many photos by people who contacted him after an article seeking help was published in the Courier in .One was sent to the author by Sandy Darling, then aged , who now lives in Musselburgh.Sandy, who had cycled out to Thorntonloch from Stenton, is shown in the photo watching over the scene.What is interesting in this photo is how well-dressed people are.In the s, people of all classes would dress much more formally than today when going somewhere which would involve meeting other people.There was also little attention paid to health and safety in .In a photo from the now defunct Illustrated London News, the people are standing right next to the dead and dying whales.If this tragedy happened today, the public would be kept well away.Dr Herringrsquos book contains many recollections of people who stood next to ndash and in some cases on ndash the whales. ndashThey remembered the poignancy of the scene the late Jean Budge said: ldquoIt was terribly sad ndash all these beautul creatures dying on the beach.Many also remembered it as an amazing scene and Ian Porteous recalled: ldquoIt was a spectacular scene with all these black whales on the beach.This highlights the fact there was no television in Scotland until  ndash and the internet was another  years away. People had never seen whales before, except in books.Dr Herring is still collecting peoplersquos memories of the whale stranding, which remains one of the major East Lothian events of the past  years. His book is available by emailing him at herring@gmail

title: second-bid-cctv-cameras-dunbar-harbour
story: Dunbar Harbour Trust had plans thrown out by East Lothian Council earlier this year.The new plans, lodged with East Lothian Council, show two cameras and two network antennae on Lamer Island, beside the east wall of Dunbar Battery.Lamer Island Battery is an th-century lsquoD-planrsquo bastion of squared sandstone rubble construction, listed as being of special architectural or historic interest, Category B.It was built as a civil defence outpost and has subsequently had ious uses, including as an infectious diseases hospital in the th century and a military hospital during the First World War.The original proposals were turned down by the local authority as it was felt they would be ldquoan incongruous feature.Dunbar Harbour Trust had applied for planning permission to ldquoaddress requests from the fishing community and generally improve safety and security coverage around the harbour.However, planning officers for East Lothian Council rejected the proposals, ruling that the two cameras would not be an attractive additionThe revised proposals show the cameras would be a few metres to the east of the site previously proposed.Dunbar Harbour Trust has carried out work to bring the Battery back to le and provide access to it for all.It is currently in use as an interpretation building and amphitheatre.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: museum-moves-exhibitions-online-due-covid-19
story: John Muirrsquos Birthplace had a number of exhibitions planned for throughout the year.The venue has been closed due to the coronavirus but will now take things online.A spokesman for the High Street attraction encouraged people to visit the centrersquos website: www.jmbt.org.uk.He said: ldquoWe are very excited that we have new pages where we can continue to show exhibitions we have planned but are unable to show this year.ldquoWe also hope to be able to keep adding to this offer to show past exhibitions, so make sure you bookmark the pages so you can keep ing as the content grows!ldquoTo begin with we are bringing information on John Muir, Earth, Planet, Universe, our summer exhibition that should have opened on April .ldquoCurated by Friends of John Muirrsquos Birthplace, the exhibition focuses on John Muirrsquos legacy and his role as an environmental activist and successful campaigner and his relevance for our situation today in addressing the climate crisis.ldquoHowever, we have paused to reflect on the content of the exhibition in the light of the current COVID- crisis.ldquoFollowing on from a successful run online and in the Museum before we closed, we are also delighted to bring you Sheila Simrsquos Gardens of East Lothian.ldquoThe beautul photos are an oasis of calm, reminding us of nature continuing to thrive even although we are unable to spend time enjoying it at the current time.ldquoEast Lothian has a long and proud heritage of gardening, and has produced several horticultural pioneers.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: new-town-top-low-carbon-location
story: The local authority has lodged its vision for the future with Scottish Ministers as they prepare to create a new National Policy Framework .But it has warned its ambitions must not be sacriced in a rush to kickstart the economy as the nation comes out of lockdown.In an opening statement to their submission, officials expressed concern that new developments may lose sight of the long-term ambition they have for the county.They tell the Scottish Government: ldquoThe current challenges brought about by coronavirus may have lasting effects on the economy.ldquoWhile demand for new development will , it is important that, in the short term, standards in new development are not prejudiced to stimulate growth.ldquoThe ambitions around climate change, ecology, health and well-being, equality, connectivity, inclusive growth and place-making remain.East Lothian Council wants the National Development designation given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in previous frameworks to be expanded to include the new town of Blindwells which is underway on nearby land, in the new NPF.The council believes that National Development status for the wider area including nearby Blindwells would support ambitions for sustainable growth and an emerging vision for the area to be an influential, innovative, healthy and carbon neutral location.And they say the larger site could become one of Scotlands top ten low carbon locations.While the boundaries of the area are still to be finalised it could stretch out to cover existing communities of Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesperson for Environment, said it was important the county continued to plan for the future during the Covid- outbreak.And he said it was important the ambitions set out before the lockdown continued to be at the heart of decisions made.He said: ldquoWe are ambitious for East Lothian and want to see it remain as a great place in which to live and work, which is well connected with good employment opportunities and sustainability principles at its heart.The local authority has asked Scottish Ministers to designate an area known as The Blindwells, Cockenzie and Climate Change Zone, as a National Development.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoWe want to see the new settlement at Blindwells developed as a fantastic community in which to live and work.ldquoIt should be a zero emissions community embracing climate change objectives and embracing blue green infrastructure and bioersity.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site offers signicant opportunity in terms of economic development and employment and work continues to understand its potential.ldquoIn our proposal for a National Development, we are suggesting that a Climate Change Zone is created between these sites, and including parts of, neighbouring communities and sites.ldquoWe believe this wider area, part of the former East Lothian coalfield, could be one of Scotlandrsquos top  locations for low carbon, sustainable inclusive growth and we are determined to grasp the opportunity.ldquoWe are making our case in a submission to the Scottish Government and will be carrying out public engagement on the extent of our vision for the area in due course.

title: tesco-clubcard-vouchers-set-expire-extended-november-2020
story: The extension comes as Tesco say customers across the UK have not been shopping as frequently as before the lockdown period began in March.Herersquos everything you need to know.Changing shopping habitsWith some customers unable to visit stores at all during lockdown, and others visiting less frequently, shopping habits have changed over the past few months.Tesco has reported that visits to the supermarket have halved since lockdown, but basket sizes have doubled.Clubcard vouchers extendedHowever, those with Clubcard vouchers could now be struggling to spend them before they expire,they cannot get to a store or book a delivery slot.Tesco has therefore issued a statement to shoppers stating that Clubcard points that were due to expire this month will now be extended, Manchester Evening News reports.Zoe Evans, of Tescos customer engagement centre, said:"We appreciate that, for many reasons, most of us arenrsquot shopping as often as we did before lockdown."As a little help from Clubcard, we want to give you more time to use your vouchers which were due to expire on May , ."Any vouchers issued in May  will now not expire until November , , giving you an extra six months to use them."Well update the expiry date on your digital vouchers, and well continue to accept paper vouchers in-store until the extended expiry date. We really hope it helps, and take care."

title: soaps-emmerdale-hollyoaks-coronation-street-can-begin-filming
story: The cast and crew of the UKrsquos favourite soap operas stopped filming prior to the lockdown in March, and since then TV networks have rationed episodes to keep them on air for as long as possible.This week, the programmes were allowedtoto filming, as long as they are able to follow new safety and social distancing guidelines.How will soaps adapt amid coronavirus When filming does resume, however, there will have to be changes made to the way scripts are written, scenes are shot, and how cast and crew interact.Coronation Street producer Iain MacLeod said:ldquoScripts are changing all the time - we have talked a lot about whether Coronation Street would exist in a parallel world or had a coronavirus in it.ldquoThe Coronation Street we love reflects modern Britain albeit heightened. So to not reference it wouldnrsquot feel right. It has to exist but people also tune in for escapism and to see dramatic stories and stuff they donrsquot normally see in their own lives.Itrsquos likely that soaps will have to follow ldquoCovid- secure guidelines, as released by the UK government.What are lsquoCovid- securersquo guidelines In a  page document published by the UK government - titled Our Plan to Rebuild: The UK Governmentrsquos COVID- recovery strategy - guidelines were released on how workplaces, including studios, that reopen can make themselves ldquoCovid- secure.These guidelines include:A spokesperson for the Department for Culture said: ldquoThe government is working closely with the screen sector to understand how dferent types of productions can comply with social distancing guidelines, and give confidence to people in the TV and film industries that there are safe ways in which they canto work.Which soaps can start filming again No inidual soap has been given the go ahead by the government yet, but the consultation around broadcasting and filming guidelines will close on Friday, May , so more information should be coming soon.Because many soaps have a bank of pre-filmed episodes, you might not even see your favourite soap come off the air as they begin to gear up to resume filming.

We deem them, heroes.While many of us sit safely inside our home social distancing, the few times we venture outside for fresh air, these people are heading into public places on a regular basis to help.
